subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: The 2012 Olympics Logo: Design That Divided a Nation
description: A quick, practical guide to The 2012 Olympics Logo: Design That Divided a Nation.

hook.text: London's 2012 Olympics logo cost Â£400,000 and was so controversial that 50,000 people signed a petition against it.

buildup.text: Wolff Olins designed jagged, angular numerals spelling '2012' in hot pink. The public was horrified.

discovery.text: 48,000 people signed a petition demanding a redesign. Iran threatened to boycott, seeing hidden text in the shapes.

twist.text: By the time the Games started, the logo had grown on people. The events overshadowed the controversy.

climax.text: The 2012 logo proves that bold design provokes initial hate but can succeed if the experience delivers.

punchline.text: The most hated logo became the face of one of the most loved Olympics.

quiz.question: How did public opinion on the 2012 Olympics logo change over time?
options: Initially hated, it was accepted once the successful Games started
